946C0C7F7FFB4741B4AB678B2E72B3C0.description:
Some ways humans can mitigate the impact of
loss of biodiversity include creating protected
areas, use of habitat corridors, promoting
sustainable land use practices, and restoring
lost habitats.

9BEE5FF30BB24CAAA2DF073641E1DF13.description:
Some organisms have been somewhat
or completely domesticated and are now
managed for economic returns, such as
honeybee colonies and domestic livestock.
This domestication can have a negative impact
on the biodiversity of that organism.

F4970B4FC730488C8E47CD0838988CF7.description:
Global climate change can cause habitat loss
via changes in temperature, precipitation, and
sea level rise.

FB6B5C4A3C8E4D72979D96C39F4C1B93.description:
The scale of habitat fragmentation that has an
adverse effect on the inhabitants of a given
ecosystem will vary from species to species
within that ecosystem.

EFB2794B241049C6A4C0AC26B67225A1.description:
Habitat fragmentation occurs when large
habitats are broken into smaller, isolated areas.
Causes of habitat fragmentation include the
construction of roads and pipelines, clearing
for agriculture or development, and logging.

97F607C7882D42AFB1EA086484DF9203.description:
HIPPCO (habitat destruction, invasive species,
population growth, pollution, climate change,
and over exploitation) describes the main
factors leading to a decrease in biodiversity.

0925CE6E743B44BC92D5E30931DFFCDB.description:
Explain how human activities
affect biodiversity and
strategies to combat
the problem.

A00056B1F8D2475FB4F0E3224755DDF7.description:
The health of a species is closely tied to its ecosystem, and minor environmental
changes can have a large impact.

D125FE7B52204DFD89D33040BB55EE3A.description:
Strategies to protect animal populations
include criminalizing poaching, protecting
animal habitats, and legislation.

840202F2BC724DF59D6EBD464DB8BE16.description:
Species in a given ecosystem compete for
resources like territory, food, mates, and
habitat, and this competition may lead to
endangerment or extinction.

B0D2C7E10EE540FE8EA37F6DCF854BC5.description:
Selective pressures are any factors that
change the behaviors and fitness of organisms
within an environment.

9CB909D45CA54F7AAAA962C05CE5A0CD.description:
Not all species will be in danger of extinction
when exposed to the same changes in their
ecosystem. Species that are able to adapt to
changes in their environment or that are able
to move to a new environment are less likely to
face extinction.

7369DD72F22B45C1B7C4580FD4D7971E.description:
A variety of factors can lead to a species
becoming threatened with extinction,
such as being extensively hunted, having
limited diet, being outcompeted by invasive
species, or having specific and limited habitat
requirements.

A530E6AAEF8E405D968B5CC8FEBF27B7.description:
Explain how species become
endangered and strategies to
combat the problem.

FB9C61EB87B442E3933F676C50F59171.description:
The health of a species is closely tied to its ecosystem, and minor environmental
changes can have a large impact.

C9C4B0A70A264D46867D1BD7B1919B01.description:
Invasive species can be controlled through a
variety of human interventions.

500EE112E94A4919ABA083A933EDE76B.description:
Invasive species are often generalist,
r-selected species and therefore may
outcompete native species for resources.

B4D658DF639C46A7B151EBDA9885DF07.description:
Invasive species are species that can live,
and sometimes thrive, outside of their normal
habitat. Invasive species can sometimes be
beneficial, but they are considered invasive
when they threaten native species.

F4CE808E6D4A436E9B722F559213B23A.description:
Explain the environmental
problems associated
with invasive species and
strategies to control them.Â

54695F2AE6B84882A90F7871EFE64316.description:
The health of a species is closely tied to its ecosystem, and minor environmental
changes can have a large impact.

9AE89EBFCDBF4EE3BCEFCA7C959AAE75.description:
Ocean acidification damages coral because
acidification makes it difficult for them to form
shells, due to the loss of calcium carbonate.

AB8E2C4E8006428A9EE2C9E4DDFE6F70.description:
Anthropogenic activities that contribute
to ocean acidification are those that lead
to increased CO2 concentrations in the
atmosphere: burning of fossil fuels, vehicle
emissions, and deforestation.

6CFD8D722EC54B32BD4FE5CB0C626585.description:
As more CO2 is released into the atmosphere,
the oceans, which absorb a large part of that
CO2, become more acidic.

9421CC658BDE45C686B75CDFD97D5A41.description:
Ocean acidification is the decrease in pH of
the oceans, primarily due to increased CO2
concentrations in the atmosphere, and can be
expressed as chemical equations.

96BF82DF496440898944E2DFCD5B8100.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of ocean acidification.

D8D9FEAFFA994D75AAFA3C9698EAA663.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.Â

EFEE59C1B3F94BCC8DC054BE9A4BAFDD.description:
Ocean warming is causing coral bleaching,
which occurs when the loss of algae within
corals cause the corals to bleach white. Some
corals recover and some die.

1CF7F644869F4156A46BE1B80663A83B.description:
Ocean warming can affect marine species in a
variety of ways, including loss of habitat, and
metabolic and reproductive changes.

B8C3D2455C554260A5DCDD6C8A9F325D.description:
Ocean warming is caused by the increase in
greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

85F9B51A34564A4AA8EAC8AAD47CAF41.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of ocean warming.

C4C1D7128D334C0BBDB958198E177CD2.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

A154CEB5561A407999749FC21085D47D.description:
One consequence of the loss of ice and snow
in polar regions is the effect on species that
depend on the ice for habitat and food.

AC7663AAA1A5494481F7D4A14A8E217F.description:
Global climate change response time in the
Arctic is due to positive feedback loops
involving melting sea ice and thawing tundra,
and the subsequent release of greenhouse
gases like methane.

9C12A4A05F5542A8BE62A8E62A7552FF.description:
As the Earth warms, this ice and snow melts,
meaning less solar energy is radiated back into
space and instead is absorbed by the Earthâs
surface. This in turn causes more warming of
the polar regions.Â

DC5BA6FCB6B543CE926CA828AB68CAF5.description:
Earthâs polar regions are showing faster
response times to global climate change
because ice and snow in these regions reflect
the most energy back out to space, leading to a
positive feedback loop.

95728B701FC84B1790D40780FE78391F.description:
Climate change can affect soil through
changes in temperature and rainfall, which can
impact soilâs viability and potentially increase
erosion.

3D507920769445E09D3E53F231FA2B13.description:
Oceanic currents, or the ocean conveyor belt,
carry heat throughout the world. When these
currents change, it can have a big impact on
global climate, especially in coastal regions.Â

7EEA43F40A074FFDB9CA84C7E8EB6D79.description:
Winds generated by atmospheric circulation
help transport heat throughout the Earth.
Climate change may change circulation
patterns, as temperature changes may impact
Hadley cells and the jet stream.

E7F8BA4F3ECD4CD8A909723AD4565BC2.description:
Marine ecosystems are affected by changes
in sea level, some positively, such as in newly
created habitats on now-flooded continental
shelves, and some negatively, such as deeper
communities that may no longer be in the
photic zone of seawater.

7EE19E3EEABF43AC92AC6FFF93FB3F2D.description:
Effects of climate change include rising
temperatures, melting permafrost and sea ice,
rising sea levels, and displacement of coastal
populations.

CAEB17DF09FB4C93BE8E64C43EB40A85.description:
The Earth has undergone climate change
throughout geologic time, with major shifts
in global temperatures causing periods of
warming and cooling as recorded with CO2
data and ice cores.

4044C822F0444F97BF5CCB34CE862131.description:
Explain how changes in
climate, both short- and longterm, impact ecosystems.

8C82502910A84384B483F1058FB8E562.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

D05DBAB1EAC24AC085EF3BBFD920AE4C.description:
Global climate change, caused by excess
greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, can
lead to a variety of environmental problems
including rising sea levels resulting from
melting ice sheets and ocean water expansion,
and disease vectors spreading from the
tropics toward the poles. These problems can
lead to changes in population dynamics and
population movements in response.

7FDDB131E1354CF2BD0D063D37D9BA1C.description:
Identify the threats to human
health and the environment
posed by an increase in
greenhouse gases.

B80B35182A5F4709A47E998A7385A0A2.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

BECBD229B0E2409796A8EC9DDF835937.description:
Carbon dioxide, which has a global warming
potential (GWP) of 1, is used as a reference
point for the comparison of different
greenhouse gases and their impacts on global
climate change. Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
have the highest GWP, followed by nitrous
oxide, then methane.

30515AE495584ABB96C0398990C9CA01.description:
Identify the sources and
potency of the greenhouse
gases.Â

35D727EBC930420EAF4E3F9111CB3ED8.description:
The greenhouse effect results in the surface
temperature necessary for life on Earth to
exist.

AED3BA226F0B41DD8B6BC6F4B0064196.description:
While water vapor is a greenhouse gas, it
doesnât contribute significantly to global
climate change because it has a short
residence time in the atmosphere.

3CBB37B977D2465789C1CB00120D29D0.description:
The principal greenhouse gases are carbon
dioxide, methane, water vapor, nitrous oxide,
and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

23F703389A5B46FE80BF09CE25E8608D.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

F77148E6112141FD8DBB2F1AF31D8908.description:
Ozone depletion can be mitigated by
replacing ozone-depleting chemicals with
substitutes that do not deplete the ozone
layer. Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are one
such replacement, but some are strong
greenhouse gases.

65E4A0EE3236476DB315AAB547471717.description:
Describe chemicals
used to substitute for
chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

2160FADC3C2848EDBD404614CF1681CE.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

4E9587E024854663BD49D183681B490D.description:
A decrease in stratospheric ozone increases
the UV rays that reach the Earthâs surface.
Exposure to UV rays can lead to skin cancer
and cataracts in humans.

3EDB43B1E2744920A2D58F14FC591A3C.description:
Stratospheric ozone depletion is caused
by anthropogenic factors, such as
chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), and natural
factors, such as the melting of ice crystals
in the atmosphere at the beginning of the
Antarctic spring.

4E80F9C188D04D19A3CAF0BAB4338ACB.description:
The stratospheric ozone layer is important to
the evolution of life on Earth and the continued
health and survival of life on Earth.

31342AA7BAF2413FA466FF1364834872.description:
Explain the importance of
stratospheric ozone to life
on Earth.

951E7AD83D01473FBB8CF74BAFF852FA.description: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.Â

EEEDCC138BF84D6E94552D81AE7B2979.description:
Cholera is a bacterial disease that is contracted
from infected water.

E768EA5033BC41E589446F546B31E409.description:
Zika is a virus caused by bites from infected
mosquitoes. It can be transmitted through
sexual contact.

8038D1F9844E46268A0EAD95A6C6FB43.description:
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a
viral respiratory illness that is transferred from
animals to humans.

66181C69E4F84AB9BB9617C078620FA5.description:
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a
form of pneumonia. It is transferred by inhaling
or touching infected fluids.

2EF6653342F64B02B02D5CE5F34B56DD.description:
West Nile virus is transmitted to humans via
bites from infected mosquitoes.

0F587460DAA443F0BC3078E1DBC25479.description:
Malaria is a parasitic disease caused by bites
from infected mosquitoes. It is most often
found in sub-Saharan Africa.

8D9EA2C041DF4E3CBBBACD697F5F3ECC.description:
Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that
typically attacks the lungs. It is spread by
breathing in the bacteria from the bodily fluids
of an infected person.

FD64F7FF43BF47F6A2390AE90E1AFFED.description:
Plague is a disease carried by organisms
infected with the plague bacteria. It is
transferred to humans via the bite of an
infected organism or through contact with
contaminated fluids or tissues.Â

D01B4C06679A432D9E5F0FD28CDF6500.description:
Poverty-stricken, low-income areas often lack
sanitary waste disposal and have contaminated
drinking water supplies, leading to havens
and opportunities for the spread of infectious
diseases.

9B0DAF608F2246C7B69885C77762D6CB.description:
As equatorial-type climate zones spread north
and south in to what are currently subtropical
and temperate climate zones, pathogens,
infectious diseases, and any associated vectors
are spreading into these areas where the
disease has not previously been known to occur.

54C8A168BC1F420092F890FB53D6A908.description:
Specific pathogens can occur in many
environments regardless of the appearance of
sanitary conditions.

750B7A7BD32346FCAC51B66783AD16B3.description:
Pathogens adapt to take advantage of new
opportunities to infect and spread through
human populations.

51B94F53FECE4FEA9172746BE1CD59D5.description:
Explain human pathogens
and their cycling through the
environment.

8D2D64B2953941D8B90B36ADDC7D5AEB.description:
Pollutants can have both direct and indirect impacts on the health of organisms,
including humans.

8B9C2B691154461B847F38BE5F8B93B7.description:
Respiratory problems and overall lung
function can be impacted by elevated levels of
tropospheric ozone.

A3780EBC961D452187BAA1C050403470.description:
Mesothelioma is a type of cancer caused
mainly by exposure to asbestos.

E4FE4A5A180D4FEF9EDE0301CEB7936D.description:
Dysentery is caused by untreated sewage in
streams and rivers.

F8CC0406EEA04DD8B21ED98EF44356A6.description:
It can be difficult to establish a cause and
effect between pollutants and human health
issues because humans experience exposure
to a variety of chemicals and pollutants.

DA276220DF5E426BAFF95E069DACAD9D.description:
Identify sources of human
health issues that are linked
to pollution.

25B47CD4B0D7464B9F166F6DF127E9EC.description:
Pollutants can have both direct and indirect impacts on the health of organisms,
including humans.

7016449A78164607B3BA0618C39CC74C.description:
A dose response curve describes the effect on
an organism or mortality rate in a population
based on the dose of a particular toxin or drug.

EB740BAD7B1C417FB871D7F679AA42A0.description:
Pollutants can have both direct and indirect impacts on the health of organisms,
including humans.Â

7B2FB08E01E848BC8DC115E4CE5AFED7.description:
Lethal dose 50% (LD50) is the dose of a
chemical that is lethal to 50% of the population
of a particular species.

A6C127B7143B4C0B8BA95DDCD1F1332D.description:
Pollutants can have both direct and indirect impacts on the health of organisms,
including humans.

968C8270B6EE41B28734667888A7D08A.description:
Prior to discharge, the treated water is exposed
to one or more disinfectants (usually, chlorine,
ozone, or UV light) to kill bacteria.

76FF4438EEF743489D841EF4AC47BE64.description:
Tertiary treatment is the use of ecological or
chemical processes to remove any pollutants
left in the water after primary and secondary
treatment.

56EF3E0777DB4428AD62CDB023CCC34A.description:
Secondary treatment is a biological process
in which bacteria break down organic matter
into carbon dioxide and inorganic sludge,
which settles in the bottom of a tank. The tank
is aerated to increase the rate at which the
bacteria break down the organic matter.

0A10BC8452F0421AACBE368074F7EAAF.description:
Primary treatment of sewage is the physical
removal of large objects, often through the use
of screens and grates, followed by the settling
of solid waste in the bottom of a tank.

452C2831844E4E3594172D8927F1CC15.description:
Describe best practices in
sewage treatment.

05B33193169D4736A5BD37CAC410F159.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

774833C7C9BB45EA88E3F48A0C614876.description:
The combustion of gases produced from
decomposition of organic material in landfills
can be used to turn turbines and generate
electricity. This process reduces landfill volume.

FF06E9BAF36E469697172CE8DD17E448.description:
Landfill mitigation strategies range from
burning waste for energy to restoring habitat
on former landfills for use as parks.

47E28E6CC01744FEA05B72D1F7A462BE.description:
E-waste can be reduced by recycling and
reuse. E-wastes may contain hazardous
chemicals, including heavy metals such as lead
and mercury, which can leach from landfills
into groundwater if they are not disposed
of properly.

439BF136D6C145ECBAC9FEEAA55871C8.description:
Composting is the process of organic
matter such as food scraps, paper, and yard
waste decomposing. The product of this
decomposition can be used as fertilizer.
Drawbacks to composting include odor
and rodents.

B2A25C3E7BEC4929A950650045EB821C.description:
Recycling is one way to reduce the current
global demand on minerals, but this process is
energy-intensive and can be costly.

6B604E341E494252BBBCB8D503314D1E.description:
Recycling is a process by which certain solid
waste materials are processed and converted
into new products.

A5BE8688E2F842FB8049F7F1BDE6E5B3.description:
Describe changes to current
practices that could reduce
the amount of generated
waste and their associated
benefits and drawbacks.

2149C1D2E57547A79C0BEB7C88CF2156.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.Â

D98DA8338377488F9692119EB90773B1.description:
Some countries dispose of their waste by
dumping it in the ocean. This practice, along
with other sources of plastic, has led to
large floating islands of trash in the oceans.
Additionally, wildlife can become entangled in
the waste, as well as ingest it.

39D13F07770441048F5D1D81E96D6EB2.description:
Some items are not accepted in sanitary
landfills and may be disposed of illegally,
leading to environmental problems. One
example is used rubber tires, which when left
in piles can become breeding grounds for
mosquitoes that can spread disease.

5FAC155FE62F478F83FD6336A886098C.description:
Solid waste can also be disposed of through
incineration, where waste is burned at high
temperatures. This method significantly
reduces the volume of solid waste but releases
air pollutants.

CAD40619ECA64D4DAA2B1FBB6CC84A55.description:
Factors in landfill decomposition include
the composition of the trash and conditions
needed for microbial decomposition of
the waste.

817090930F754C4C95A60456C66CB173.description:
Describe the effects of solid
waste disposal methods.

4B47515E78424DCCA71DCEDDCBC7DFF4.description:
A sanitary municipal landfill consists of a
bottom liner (plastic or clay), a storm water
collection system, a leachate collection
system, a cap, and a methane collection
system.Â

1FA4AAF8B0ED42D3B33DBA0661F45C2D.description:
Electronic waste, or e-waste, is composed
of discarded electronic devices including
televisions, cell phones, and computers.

99FAC4218F5F438D90CA5F2B4AE6CECF.description:
Solid waste is most often disposed of
in landfills. Landfills can contaminate
groundwater and release harmful gases.

42A81BA70CFA45D9A801689C803A2AE7.description:
Solid waste is any discarded material that is
not a liquid or gas. It is generated in domestic,
industrial, business, and agricultural sectors.

A0DE20F4FBB34329B973CCB101953704.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

00EC4DCAEB734A899EEBD3501AD2AFCC.description:
DDT, mercury, and PCBs are substances
that bioaccumulate and have significant
environmental impacts.

DB5D154E6AA24CED9A01EFC1F41E30A7.description:
Humans also experience harmful effects from
biomagnification, including issues with the
reproductive, nervous, and circulatory systems.

28139E731A8A48A986E90107E36CFF66.description:
Some effects that can occur in an ecosystem
when a persistent substance is biomagnified
in a food chain include eggshell thinning and
developmental deformities in top carnivores of
the higher trophic levels.

F88B9300B1F24E278561FE6E6C6932EF.description:
Describe the effects of
bioaccumulation and
biomagnification.

902B1919CB6E427EA9518035092DDF4B.description:
Biomagnification is the increase in
concentration of substances per unit of body
tissue that occurs in successively higher
trophic levels of a food chain or in a food web.

7ADBB79E67A049849FE3BBF5EB09A6BD.description:
Bioaccumulation is the selective absorption
and concentration of elements or compounds
by cells in a living organism, most commonly
fat-soluble compounds.

5076E6F737BB4B50963CBC3802C02B1B.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

57B3403F98B648F097354A285FF6609C.description:
Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) can travel
over long distances via wind and water before
being redeposited.

85BAFD0B55D44F05A63A4DDF640A7CA6.description:
Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) can be
toxic to organisms because they are soluble
in fat, which allows them to accumulate in
organismsâ fatty tissues.

A7C6CF13E3A345DCB54251B54A28E1CD.description:
Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) do not
easily break down in the environment because
they are synthetic, carbon-based molecules
(such as DDT and PCBs).

4BBEEC06EB5F4DBFA68842DA20A8D1C0.description:
Describe the effect of
persistent organic pollutants
(POPs) on ecosystems.

6370C16B771446919F123F985EB5C28F.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

EAAC0BE4B64144CF9ED05EB40BDEEA97.description:
Variations in water temperature affect the
concentration of dissolved oxygen because
warm water does not contain as much oxygen
as cold water.

1C429A7959B94AA4BF7C3D72CC64BB60.description:
Thermal pollution occurs when heat released
into the water produces negative effects to the
organisms in that ecosystem.

384BC5F489AA4E35AA28D53D6331A711.description:
Describe the effects of
thermal pollution on aquatic
ecosystems.

BA0E5FDD19C940A3BC80FD0A67D8190C.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

1CCCD342FC104EE8A780897C60C2B91F.description:
Anthropogenic causes of eutrophication are
agricultural runoff and wastewater release.

0188BAB43D3843CD93981B84EB10D119.description:
Compared to eutrophic waterways,
oligotrophic waterways have very low amounts
of nutrients, stable algae populations, and high
dissolved oxygen.

D4C0A048542749CE9223BB37BAC161AA.description:
Hypoxic waterways are those bodies of water
that are low in dissolved oxygen.

107FA3C8DBA6412C9A0C0FBED94FC8CC.description:
The increase in nutrients in eutrophic aquatic
environments causes an algal bloom. When the
algal bloom dies, microbes digest the algae, along
with the oxygen in the water, leading to a decrease
in the dissolved oxygen levels in the water. The
lack of dissolved oxygen can result in large
die-offs of fish and other aquatic organisms.

A6F6116FE4B0465DB64FAC6B7C7DFE9D.description:
Eutrophication occurs when a body of water is
enriched in nutrients.

A97E47EEC83C4DF69C35C7C765039BD7.description:
Explain the environmental
effects of excessive use of
fertilizers and detergents on
aquatic ecosystems.

2C83015BB261481A9CCFA29AC2D38355.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

9D744ACBE75F4A55865ECCC877A375BE.description:
Threats to wetlands and mangroves include
commercial development, dam construction,
overfishing, and pollutants from agriculture and
industrial waste.

887FDA2C40044204B660417840FC2821.description:
Wetlands provide a variety of ecological
services, including water purification, flood
protection, water filtration, and habitat.

15A960AD62CE420AA2390CE65615A485.description:
Wetlands are areas where water covers the soil,
either part or all of the time.

7878A75D111B45D08C8440BCC5919015.description:
Describe the impacts of
human activity on wetlands
and mangroves.

DB7DCB9522404C6CBC9650F6F35AD42D.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

68A22F373CCD47A7ACE1EAE8863E5C81.description:
Human Impacts
on Wetlands and
Mangroves

037A2E39C0D14C299136FE707ECA2C15.description:
Endocrine disruptors can lead to birth
defects, developmental disorders, and gender
imbalances in fish and other species.

38345CA27B11429FAE115B9DBAFB6A2F.description:
Describe the effects of
endocrine disruptors on
ecosystems.

F4E975FCD137426D90B53FF7C09AADB4.description:
Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that can
interfere with the endocrine system of animals.

E297C4F39D0045168A5F0145B6B594E4.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

01B34658A7B64100B78EB0CE32A557C8.description:
When elemental sources of mercury enter
aquatic environments, bacteria in the water
convert it to highly toxic methylmercury

45EA58B80E804EC18833BFD5BDAC5297.description:
Increased sediment in waterways can reduce
light infiltration, which can affect primary
producers and visual predators. Sediment can
also settle, disrupting habitats.

B69614518DD84A48994904706CFB4B56.description:
Litter that reaches aquatic ecosystems,
besides being unsightly, can create intestinal
blockage and choking hazards for wildlife and
introduce toxic substances to the food chain.Â

842895AF0D99407F94BEE0B7CD07E148.description:
Heavy metals used for industry, especially
mining and burning of fossil fuels, can reach
the groundwater, impacting the drinking
water supply.

F7BC085340E34158A523DC0D39FC3E01.description:
An oxygen sag curve is a plot of dissolved
oxygen levels versus the distance from a
source of pollution, usually excess nutrients
and biological refuse.

4A2D86D9BB2E47B98CDD5C506CA64F87.description:
Oceanic dead zones are areas of low oxygen
in the worldâs oceans caused by increased
nutrient pollution.

F65ADDA3E0604F999A25C56F8244323E.description:
Oil that washes up on the beach can have
economic consequences on the fishing and
tourism industries.

3B9FEAD0902B4DB49C3FA05F8A31CFAE.description:
Oil spills in marine waters cause organisms to
die from the hydrocarbons in oil. Oil that floats
on the surface of water can coat the feathers
of birds and fur of marine mammals. Some
components of oil sink to the ocean floor,
killing some bottom-dwelling organisms.

356B14CC31D64CC9ACDD6D0BAE8EAF64.description:
Coral reefs have been suffering damage due to
a variety of factors, including increasing ocean
temperature, sediment runoff, and destructive
fishing practices.

2B70121F14934BB1B4D7745B19B6B07B.description:
Organisms have a range of tolerance for
various pollutants. Organisms have an
optimum range for each factor where they can
maintain homeostasis. Outside of this range,
organisms may experience physiological stress,
limited growth, reduced reproduction, and in
extreme cases, death.

73FC49E79BBE46C0AE42F17C69505D91.description:
Describe the impacts
of human activities on
aquatic ecosystems.

2688CAB325E54E0EBEA77778048425E2.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

F30980D8A9C44441989E8E6BFD5B05D2.description:
Nonpoint sources of pollution are diffused and
can therefore be difficult to identify, such as

E4E8CB2E08B94C7B82BB75917110A972.description:
A point source refers to a single, identifiable

waste discharge pipe.

9EC57F20274542A3A8F9ED5857CCBCFD.description:
Identify differences between
point and nonpoint sources
of pollution.

F73DE380740E45BBA0456FB1C1288E00.description:
Human activities, including the use of resources, have physical, chemical, and
biological consequences for ecosystems.

Some effects of noise pollution on animals in

migratory routes.

domestic and industrial activity.

5AA5ADB542B545EA9281EBB817D5AECA.description:
Noise pollution is sound at levels high enough
to cause physiological stress and hearing loss.

47ED36C8B9584F15B37F4643C2719335.description:

that result in noise pollution
and its effects.

atmosphere.

A5169345BA4746F78975426F43B3CC46.description:
Regional differences in soils and bedrock affect
the impact that acid deposition has on the
regionâsuch as limestone bedrockâs ability to
neutralize the effect of acid rain on lakes and
ponds.

842D7F7C78AF405CAC7D1F39C2970DD7.description:
Acid rain and deposition can lead to the
acidification of soils and bodies of water and
corrosion of human-made structures.

Acid deposition mainly affects communities
that are downwind from coal-burning power
plants.

FEB6CECA6B8C427EB5C5DF5CDBAF8667.description:
Describe the effects of
acid deposition on the
environment.

105A7CFA67094233A88E9DEE818662D3.description:
Nitric oxides that cause acid deposition

C13C3D5CF5AB4A77B7E9D6E3EC856243.description:
Acid rain and deposition is due to nitrogen
oxides and sulfur oxides from anthropogenic
and natural sources in the atmosphere.

79D3B158420B4DA096A0FA40A9920222.description:
Human activities have physical, chemical, and biological consequences for the
atmosphere.Â

electrostatic precipitators.

A catalytic converter is an air pollution control

DC79089BFEF646D6B64A5238FF9CC12E.description:

ADE077026FFF48708096F82287F0C9B1.description:
Methods to reduce air pollutants include
regulatory practices, conservation practices,
and alternative fuels.

2483D0387CE145B88BBE67BF9EDD571F.description:
Explain how air pollutants can
be reduced at the source.

8E49BC51F1A54D20A6E5E2366FB5814A.description:
Human activities have physical, chemical, and biological consequences for the
atmosphere.Â

F37353F05F854018971640E7C74F7226.description:

leading cause of lung cancer in America.

7EF88DDB184D49049F8154F56E67F436.description:

up through the soil and enters homes via the

A18FA6670C26482B93045491FE1C27AB.description:

Photochemical smog often forms in urban

oxygen and sunlight.

effects of photochemical
smog and methods to
reduce it.

atmosphere.Â

pollutants.

particulate matter.Â

Coal combustion releases air pollutants
including carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, toxic

energy around a home include adjusting the
thermostat to reduce the use of heat and
air conditioning, conserving water, use of

landscaping.

consequences.

Wind energy is a renewable, clean source of
energy. However, birds and bats may be killed if

power generation on the
environment.

Wind turbines use the kinetic energy of moving
air to spin a turbine, which in turn converts
the mechanical energy of the turbine into
electricity.

3DEF72F7982C4EFEB943A5A6B92CCD1B.description:
Describe the use of wind
energy in power generation.Â

29F905CE448C49D2AE87CC5B66269724.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.Â

Hydrogen fuel cells have low environmental
impact and produce no carbon dioxide when

9B284BB3B08C4CBD804D1CBD167D4232.description:
Describe the effects of the
use of hydrogen fuel cells
in power generation on the
environment.

Hydrogen fuel cells are an alternate to nonrenewable fuel sources. They use hydrogen as
fuel, combining the hydrogen and oxygen in the

5F988CE58ACB4856B4846E261AF6EC85.description:

fuel cells in power generation.

E8FAD45FB0AA4899A5F97688F3B93363.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

can be prohibitively expensive, as is not
easily accessible in many parts of the world.

hydrogen sulfide.

Describe the effects of the
use of geothermal energy
in power generation on
the environment.

Geothermal energy is obtained by using the
heat stored in the Earthâs interior to heat up
water, which is brought back to the surface
as steam. The steam is used to drive an
electric generator.

0B7C577835AD4770B7AC431B7E8B907A.description:
Describe the use of
geothermal energy in power
generation.

consequences.

pollution or waste, but construction of the
power plants can be expensive, and there may
be a loss of or change in habitats following the
construction of dams.

CDCA1329474B46A8BFDFDBB78989A133.description:
Describe the effects of the
use of hydroelectricity in
power generation on the
environment.

Tidal energy uses the energy produced by tidal

Hydroelectric power can be generated in
several ways. Dams built across rivers collect

2C0527DD6A864E0599043D212FBBDE8F.description:
Describe the use of
hydroelectricity in power
generation.

Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.Â

Solar energy systems have low environmental
impact and produce clean energy, but they can
be expensive. Large solar energy farms may
negatively impact desert ecosystems.Â

0C30E20D03C4461EBCA5D249C1F21F5B.description:
Describe the effects of
the use of solar energy in
power generation on the
environment.

cannot be collected or stored.

captured from the sun.

Photovoltaic solar cells capture light energy

availability of sunlight.

energy in power generation.Â

consequences.Â

gasoline. Burning ethanol does not introduce
additional carbon into the atmosphere via
combustion, but the energy return on energy
investment for ethanol is low.

Burning of biomass produces heat for energy at

particulates, and volatile organic compounds.

deforestation.

3059A1DE246544ABA03C87287E4AF135.description:
Describe the effects of
the use of biomass in
power generation on the
environment.

67DBC0EC8A3846688263C0E702A52C72.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

A radioactive elementâs half-life can be used to
calculate a variety of things, including the rate
of decay and the radioactivity level at specific
points in time.Â

disasters led to the release of radiation. These
releases have had short- and long-term
impacts on the environment.

AC8DDAD0E06D41E9BD927AAEC44B70E4.description:
Describe the effects of the
use of nuclear energy on the
environment.

energy source. Nuclear power is considered
a cleaner energy source because it does not
produce air pollutants, but it does release
thermal pollution and hazardous solid waste.

time, which leads to the problems associated

radioactive isotope loses energy by emitting
radiation.

Nuclear power is generated through fission,
where atoms of Uranium-235, which are stored
in fuel rods, are split into smaller parts after being
struck by a neutron. Nuclear fission releases a
large amount of heat, which is used to generate
steam, which powers a turbine and generates
electricity.

2509331352C84EFE87160A51D7BF25F6.description:
Describe the use of nuclear
energy in power generation.Â

31D5345155F545EE96E4B3AE4933D8AC.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

Hydrologic fracturing (fracking) can cause
groundwater contamination and the release of
volatile organic compounds.

fuels on the environment.

Humans use a variety of methods to extract
fossil fuels from the earth for energy
generation.Â Â

those fuels to generate heat, which then turns
water into steam. That steam turns a turbine,
which generates electricity.

energy.

4C87F326B53C43CB919973F9F3F0A3E7.description:

methods of fossil fuels in
power generation.

Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

gas, is not uniform and depends on regionsâ

Fossil fuels can be made into specific fuel types
for specialized uses (e.g., in motor vehicles).Â

Crude oil can be recovered from tar sands,

Natural gas, the cleanest of the fossil fuels, is

Three types of coal used for fuel are lignite,

70FA12979E4E4952A9C525BDF2940129.description:
Wood is commonly used as fuel in the forms
of firewood and charcoal. It is often used

accessible.

7290203616574972BA253F9C3A81D25E.description:
Identify types of fuels and
their uses.

FAEB5F249A4E450C97C3962460F3FED8.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

Availability, price, and governmental regulations
influence which energy sources people use
and how they use them.

A3C7493CD62C4FAA9F271046AF5E86DB.description:
As the world becomes more industrialized, the
demand for energy increases.Â

B736AA166E2C414B88C93F3FF3B0405B.description:
As developing countries become more
developed, their reliance on fossil fuels for
energy increases.

A052D51D6BD1466586FB537DB0E1CB1B.description:
The most widely used sources of energy

C97BB015728943B2B1C0F4F6B230032D.description:
The use of energy resources is not evenly
distributed between developed and developing
countries.

4BC8CE2EAA0A4660A823CA548EAF03C4.description:
Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.Â

be replenished naturally, at or near the rate of
consumption, and reused.

Nonrenewable energy sources are those that
exist in a fixed amount and involve energy

3FD20DD31C2C4B89A3AAA6EEC55A7C4D.description:
Identify differences between
nonrenewable and renewable
energy sources.

Humans use energy from a variety of sources, resulting in positive and negative
consequences.

order to reduce the occurrence of natural fires.

trees.

Some of the methods for mitigating
deforestation include reforestation, using

wood.

5536826C47834357A7B9C8E0B45A5F3E.description:

mitigating human impact

Humans can mitigate their impact on land and water resources through

Integrated pest management (IPM) minimizes

60ABFCFAD892446D9C08C9A7408EAE62.description:
The use of integrated pest management (IPM)

drawbacks of integrated pest

Integrated pest management (IPM) is a

Humans can mitigate their impact on land and water resources through

99FC99F3D13D496F8FE9260759F1DC66.description:
Humans can mitigate their impact on land and water resources through
sustainable use.

EEF71EB9A4FB424F8B1FE09D4A313E38.description:
Sustainable yield is the amount of a renewable

F7341584E3A64264BFE4EF7BA52F5355.description:
Sustainability refers to humans living on Earth
and their use of resources without depletion

Environmental indicators that can guide
humans to sustainability include biological

human population, and resource depletion.

AB5F8BA42DC7466CADB5581DDA372D72.description:
Humans can mitigate their impact on land and water resources through

495B57F0502E429799FD16B6D801F69C.description:
Urban sprawl is the change in population
distribution from high population density
areas to low density suburbs that spread into

F978934517174BBDB6ED9BD8F99EFAC5.description:
Impervious surfaces are human-made
structuresâsuch as roads, buildings,

1A7AE7F823294559ADA3F7ACD1691471.description:
Urbanization, through the burning of fossil

the atmosphere.

D9F2605EC99E48DFADCCE3FE6E983B6B.description:
Urbanization can lead to depletion of resources
and saltwater intrusion in the hydrologic cycle.Â

9459B4C4173A484F94C07214FB92FD08.description:
Describe the effects
of urbanization on the
environment.

EB5BFCCA7EF34E349AFF8EAEB9473420.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

EFA8E8A121C54AA8B345B901AB3DF650.description:
As coal reserves get smaller, due to a lack
of easily accessible reserves, it becomes
necessary to access coal through subsurface
mining, which is very expensive.

4E9808D1BF5C473180F5160CD6CA21E4.description:
Mining wastes include the soil and rocks that are
moved to gain access to the ore and the waste,
called slag and tailings that remain when the
minerals have been removed from the ore. Mining
helps to provide low cost energy and material
necessary to make products. The mining of coal
can destroy habitats, contaminate ground water,
and release dust particles and methane.

A250BF5B38EA4B09BC68E31ED08DA093.description:
Describe ecological and
economic impacts of natural
resource extraction through
mining.

D690136CC05B46FDA5CFA798D9D40636.description:
Surface mining is the removal of large portions
of soil and rock, called overburden, in order to
access the ore underneath. An example is strip
mining, which removes the vegetation from
an area, making the area more susceptible to
erosion.

EB230A23D2D8426D8828AF3AB823F21C.description:
As the more accessible ores are mined to
depletion, mining operations are forced to
access lower grade ores. Accessing these ores
requires increased use of resources that can
cause increased waste and pollution.

B5B8F2CCB3014DD68D0992045E2FCEAD.description:
Describe natural resource
extraction through mining.

09E8D08E45BA4761B4508C34D96B7AB0.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

DF2BC33C7EB946F9B969EE77F4B6BEF6.description:
Overfishing has led to the extreme scarcity
of some fish species, which can lessen
biodiversity in aquatic systems and harm
people who depend on fishing for food
and commerce.

1D004026C2824D318773532F32AABAE0.description:
Describe causes of and
problems related to
overfishing.Â

4788487845E7435286079042CB900075.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

3590BC3CC0434B6E904794D77549AC37.description:
Less consumption of meat could reduce CO2,
methane, and N2O emissions; conserve water;
reduce the use of antibiotics and growth
hormones; and improve topsoil.

A40348EAFA874EE7BE573896986AAD2E.description:
Overgrazing can cause desertification.
Desertification is the degradation of low
precipitation regions toward being increasingly
arid until they become deserts.

444EB5C2183F42A991D97BB1162096DE.description:
Overgrazing occurs when too many animals
feed on a particular area of land. Overgrazing
causes loss of vegetation, which leads to soil
erosion.

006C15F708F546B484A1909BFA1BF8A5.description:
Free range grazing allows animals to graze
on grass during their entire lifecycle. Meat
from free range animals tends to be free
from antibiotics and other chemicals used in
feedlots. Organic waste from these animals
acts as fertilizer. Free range grazing requires
large areas of land and the meat produced is
more expensive for consumers.

F1A9D28F8769498AB31A77F986534142.description:
Concentrated animal feeding operation
(CAFOs) are used as a way to quickly get
livestock ready for slaughter. They tend to be
crowded, and animals are fed grains or feed
that are not as suitable as grass. Additionally,
feedlots generate a large amount of organic
waste, which can contaminate ground and
surface water. The use of feedlots are less
expensive than other methods, which can keep
costs to consumers down.

57B682162532453A9A9A81A7078DDBCB.description:
Meat production is less efficient than
agriculture; it takes approximately 20 times
more land to produce the same amount of
calories from meat as from plants.

A05C40D1DFDF42C19A792FC564F1AAA1.description:
Describe the benefits and
drawbacks of different
methods of meat production.Â

B8C741888C404993B206683BE4B9660D.description:
Methods of meat production include
concentrated animal feeding operations
(CAFOs), also called feedlots, and free-range
grazing.

0A402DCEA0274E63966D562CE84C173D.description:
Identify different methods of
meat production.

F9C1B9742B0645C9874B428349FAC764.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

61B3C1DECFC349209F7F1A069A1034FE.description:
Crops can be genetically engineered to
increase their resistance to pests and diseases.
However, using genetically engineered crops
in planting or other ways can lead to loss of
genetic diversity of that particular crop.

CC765DF3D678490AB99836D35394D64F.description:
One consequence of using common
pest-control methods such as pesticides,
herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, and
insecticides is that organisms can become
resistant to them through artificial selection.
Pest control decreases crop damage by pest
and increases crop yields.

F5AEA31712A9464AA6A86B20FA8D387A.description:
Describe the benefits and
drawbacks of different
methods of pest control.

91B9FA4E5B12476FB722204B3FB7B93C.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

2D1E14A2CDAC472BA152F8E2ED6CD42B.description:
Aquifers can be severely depleted if overused
for agricultural irrigation, as has happened
to the Ogallala Aquifer in the central
United States.

899A8E029D1E450CA294033A4918EB94.description:
Salinization occurs when the salts in
groundwater remain in the soil after the water
evaporates. Over time, salinization can make
soil toxic to plants.

B4AE4182FE4E48459CE8EC2D747E8D4B.description:
Drip irrigation uses perforated hoses to release
small amounts of water to plant roots. This
system is the most efficient, with only about
5% of water lost to evaporation and runoff.
However, this system is expensive and so is not
often used.

040DFE4C45E74D6DAF2A28F7EB9A17B6.description:
Spray irrigation involves pumping ground water
into spray nozzles across an agricultural field.
This system is more efficient than flood and
furrow irrigation, with only 1/4 or less of the water
lost to evaporation or runoff. However, spray
systems are more expensive than flood and
furrow irrigation, and also requires energy to run.Â

BB3E1FA1A41F4241BBAE867252ED83D5.description:
Flood irrigation involves flooding an agricultural
field with water. This system sees about 20%
of the water lost to evaporation and runoff. This
can also lead to waterlogging of the soil.Â

127118DCFC7A4100B3ADF140CA314626.description:
Furrow irrigation involves cutting furrows
between crop rows and filling them with water.
This system is inexpensive, but about 1/3 of the
water is lost to evaporation and runoff.Â

01E9DF0A3FC04BBDB4FAC1A4EF89195B.description:
Waterlogging occurs when too much water
is left to sit in the soil, which raises the water
table of groundwater and inhibits plantsâ ability
to absorb oxygen through their roots.

DFE0880BBB5E43E78C48548E614E76B2.description:
Describe the benefits and
drawbacks of different
methods of irrigation.

F72C537477544C089BE2D6FA895F62A8.description:
Types of irrigation include drip irrigation, flood
irrigation, furrow irrigation, drip irrigation, and
spray irrigation.

317E11E74D0C4771B417814515F29DBC.description:
The largest human use of freshwater is for
irrigation (70%).

7D52AE4DB1944B7297A800857114D642.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

environmental damage include tilling, slashand-burn farming, and the use of fertilizers.

A8FD6E3377CC4ADA893BE4EA7F03A554.description:

practices that cause

E12A6721991A4E269347D122FD8917CB.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

Mechanization of farming can increase profits
and efficiency for farms. It can also increase

CC66098211EB4E9E9163AFD9E39E652E.description:

5550C9A40E1C4E0583067D08100536F9.description:

96EE88EBDE684B8BA1F62FC80A2C3E0C.description: When humans use natural resources, they alter natural systems.

ABD58718CC5C4E248104C40B23F42533.description:

El NiÃ±o and La NiÃ±a are influenced by

501200CD71724C608B4BB050CFC5E4BD.description:

4EC3A1B73E8342169DBA002A5BBB11C6.description:
Most of the Earthâs atmospheric processes are driven by input of energy from
the sun.

2E5E38476D8B40A2A193E675B4CA923F.description:

Most of the Earthâs atmospheric processes are driven by input of energy from

The angle of the sunâs rays determines the

D86994B25F6C460D85D6AC6C05205DDB.description:
Incoming solar radiation (insolation) is
the Earthâs main source of energy and is
dependent on season and latitude.Â

B76D542F9FFC453BBA2E2E81F4C28585.description:

affects the Earthâs surface.

2D29DDDE15AF45C19C144CD0BD1BA73E.description:
Most of the Earthâs atmospheric processes are driven by input of energy from

Characteristics of a given watershed include

681C23C0193D4D748CA5B73377C9529F.description:
Describe the characteristics
of a watershed.

factors can result in

5FAADD02683A46D6AE25196EC64A9C4F.description:
The layers of the atmosphere are based

The atmosphere is made up of major gases,

8F6C29B3B7844F938DB2A80D6FCFAA09.description:
Describe the structure and
composition of the Earthâs
atmosphere.Â

A soil texture triangle is a diagram that allows

FFFF99E9225D44849898FFFC175197CE.description:
There are a variety of methods to test the

AA0B5B1260C043179B027DBC03A778F8.description:
The particle size and composition of each soil
horizon can affect the porosity, permeability,

EFBE2862E79444FC9B48A88300C709E3.description:
Water holding capacityâthe total amount of

types. Water retention contributes to land
productivity and fertility of soils.

443C0D7BD0CF49449F57557AD13ECDE0.description:
Describe similarities and
differences between
properties of different
soil types.

9040AF38F2154602BAA155F430B90652.description: Earthâs systems interact, resulting in a state of balance over time.

84712679D90E4FDFAB0849AA120F7BEE.description:
Soils can be eroded by winds or water.
Protecting soils can protect water quality as
soils effectively filter and clean water that
moves through them.Â

C91A65730EAB469D8564D8C4C88C715B.description:
Soils are generally categorized by horizons
based on their composition and organic
material.

80EFE68A80254FE99D2A494B949EEE9E.description:
Soils are formed when parent material is
weathered, transported, and deposited.Â

8DC2CD34E18646C9B619CC03A4A41837.description:
Describe the characteristics
and formation of soil.Â

8E3262A0A0FB407EAC3A926698F277F2.description: Earthâs systems interact, resulting in a state of balance over time.

8B1E47FA4AA8491484484AD326666979.description:
An earthquake occurs when stress overcomes
a locked fault, releasing stored energy.

03917D1E5B2E40B7BA63911B6FE1682A.description:
Maps that show the global distribution of plate
boundaries can be used to determine the
location of volcanoes, island arcs, earthquakes,
hot spots, and faults.

CE1E7E557F9041FEB338DEAC2982AA50.description:
Transform boundaries can result in
earthquakes.

957B8A373219482A9B652E2998A2A801.description:
Divergent boundaries can result in seafloor
spreading, rift valleys, volcanoes, and
earthquakes.

C0CCF38CA9CC4FB38900B22E33C87010.description:
Convergent boundaries can result in
the creation of mountains, island arcs,
earthquakes, and volcanoes.Â

679748B4672D4DC3ABF68010DDA8513B.description:
Describe the geological
changes and events that
occur at convergent,
divergent, and transform
plate boundaries.

044C3F372C3C4F218F301B4ED0068A45.description: Earthâs systems interact, resulting in a state of balance over time.Â

42178B831A8C44A3828BC7F9A3FA3FA2.description:
Characteristics of developing countries include
higher infant mortality rates and more children
in the workforce than developed countries.

D150439E51084F87A519DA9001E8FC65.description:
The demographic transition refers to the
transition from high to lower birth and death
rates in a country or region as development
occurs and that country moves from a preindustrial to an industrialized economic system.
This transition is typically demonstrated
through a four-stage demographic transition
model (DTM).Â

23E67DDC3E7F44C4A9E906104334CD68.description:
Human populations change in reaction to a variety of factors, including social and
cultural factors.

584466560DE84566B8A560F6CE35D2B0.description:
The rule of 70 states that dividing the number
70 by the percentage population growth rate
approximates the populationâs doubling time.Â

891794611A5E4552B23AA8A86645FAB0.description:
Population growth can be affected by both
density-independent factors, such as major
storms, fires, heat waves, or droughts, and
density-dependent factors, such as access to
clean water and air, food availability, disease
transmission, or territory size.

73512DA98E1941E5B2E617544EC2AB0D.description:
Factors limiting global human population
include the Earthâs carrying capacity and the
basic factors that limit human population
growth as set forth by Malthusian theory.

03B1855ACEEE46CBBF9E1FB225F97D64.description:
Birth rates, infant mortality rates, and overall
death rates, access to family planning, access
to good nutrition, access to education, and
postponement of marriage all affect whether a
human population is growing or declining.

97475D583A6B4C64A2ACC77AB7DF5879.description:
Explain how human
populations experience
growth and decline.

017D643DC97F4CF8ABB0A8B645F41797.description:
Human populations change in reaction to a variety of factors, including social and
cultural factors.

B3AA8BB940F5471F9CE7CDD258C7A087.description:
Factors associated with infant mortality rates
include whether mothers have access to good
healthcare and nutrition. Changes in these
factors can lead to changes in infant mortality
rates over time.

43707DFFC5714F638AEA90CB3533ED90.description:
If fertility rate is at replacement levels, a
population is considered relatively stable.

A169EEFF0879458EA6830B1A563EBCEB.description:
Total fertility rate (TFR) is affected by the age at
which females have their first child, educational
opportunities for females, access to family
planning, and government acts and policies.

5D0AABDE0B3A47B69EF3C52F77162BF4.description:
Explain factors that affect
total fertility rate in human
populations.

2F4421C26FDB4B5585B7EB9B8E6CFD1B.description:
Human populations change in reaction to a variety of factors, including social and
cultural factors.Â

A10FD5A5B3114B70BD86E76A5985B06F.description:
A rapidly growing population will, as a rule,
have a higher proportion of younger people
compared to stable or declining populations.

B9FB94BA83A743BA9376106981C7B895.description:
Population growth rates can be interpreted
from age structure diagrams by the shape of
the structure.

1366375841F4471EA27F5BE243D0E328.description:
Human populations change in reaction to a variety of factors, including social and
cultural factors.Â

15CFC93CF3064A879978172C03C24E57.description:
When the resource base of a population
shrinks, the increased potential for unequal
distribution of resources will ultimately result
in increased mortality, decreased fecundity, or
both, resulting in population growth declining
to, or below, carrying capacity.

0C0FE2844FF14E5F8CBF2C776F03377F.description:
When the resources needed by a population
for growth are abundant, population growth
usually accelerates.

4DFCCE99854F4CD78D03A33FBF8F7757.description:
Resource availability and the total resource
base are limited and finite over all scales
of time.

077365082F1642A69CD8B3696D3B7294.description:
Population growth is limited by environmental
factors, especially by the available resources
and space.

7F41D6F8157D4A54A1C2D608DEF0740F.description:
Explain how resource
availability affects population
growth.

A4BC26BDE8644E49949E4AFB205AF77B.description: Populations change over time in reaction to a variety of factors.

A1EC16873CF04FCB8448AA001F7EF763.description:
A major ecological effect of population
overshoot is dieback of the population (often
severe to catastrophic) because the lack of
available resources leads to famine, disease,
and/or conflict.

AC74245D49434247A72CF76B43F873B5.description:
Describe the impact of
carrying capacity on
ecosystems.

9D4774A0134C4DDC92BB9260F496C5E0.description:
When a population exceeds its carrying capacity
(carrying capacity can be denoted as K),
overshoot occurs. There are environmental
impacts of population overshoot, including
resource depletion.

17ABB0EB4798412F8589A433C388000D.description: Populations change over time in reaction to a variety of factors.

9313044A93484D78BF8907EDFD2B8CC1.description:
Survivorship curves differ for K-selected and
r-selected species, with K-selected species
typically following a Type I or Type II curve and
r-selected species following a Type III curve.

3C269B2057174D2F8B9D3752AEE03003.description:
A survivorship curve is a line that displays the
relative survival rates of a cohortâa group of
individuals of the same ageâin a population,
from birth to the maximum age reached by any
one cohort member. There are Type I, Type II,
and Type III curves.Â

7A66D9116F6D462ABAC078966C85E1BC.description: Populations change over time in reaction to a variety of factors.Â

77D38F7D3FA84B1ABB2F28D1ABC5B3DD.description:
K-selected species are typically more
adversely affected by invasive species than
r-selected species, which are minimally
affected by invasive species. Most invasive
species are r-selected species.

C22B3A8FB76E4083AF4795C334FF5206.description:
Many species have reproductive strategies
that are not uniquely r-selected or K-selected,
or they change in different conditions at
different times.

61C182A23F7C48449C54DAB19F6EBB7A.description:
Biotic potential refers to the maximum
reproductive rate of a population in ideal
conditions.

C860FD8B101642F287108F36548D2F1C.description:
r-selected species tend to be small, have
many offspring, expend or invest minimal
energy for each offspring, mature early, have
short life spans, and may reproduce only once
in their lifetime. Competition for resources
in r-selected speciesâ habitats is typically
relatively low.

B957C1E5DA7549A7A269C4833D0E2279.description:
K-selected species tend to be large, have few
offspring per reproduction event, live in stable
environments, expend significant energy for
each offspring, mature after many years of
extended youth and parental care, have long
life spans/life expectancy, and reproduce more
than once in their lifetime. Competition for
resources in K-selected speciesâ habitats is
usually relatively high.

3EA167547C8849489268D93CB86980E2.description:
Identify differences between
K- and r-selected species.Â

0221A9A78BA4482880E4A457D73BC3CA.description: Populations change over time in reaction to a variety of factors.

AD463619D07F49FB81D254ED98090DA1.description:
Specialist species tend to be advantaged in
habitats that remain constant, while generalist
species tend to be advantaged in habitats that
are changing.

A93EC5F7DCF344D3ACFD8479D556E1A8.description:
Identify differences between
generalist and specialist
species.

41D05472DB684548899831A316ED8CEF.description: Populations change over time in reaction to a variety of factors.

E60CCE3F9205479493D8DC8180206C8A.description:
Succession in a disturbed ecosystem will
affect the total biomass, species richness, and
net productivity over time.

E47CFCF7029349DE990D0D7EE485162A.description:
Pioneer members of an early successional
species commonly move into unoccupied
habitat and over time adapt to its particular
conditions, which may result in the origin
of new species.

A6D112BB99124CE0A18F279094B38176.description:
Describe the effect of
ecological succession on
ecosystems.

8136236DC58A4742842B3C588F6E5628.description:
An indicator species is a plant or animal that, by
its presence, abundance, scarcity, or chemical
composition, demonstrates that some
distinctive aspect of the character or quality of
an ecosystem is present.

459DEB884DF84F86BE152000FB8A7384.description:
A keystone species in an ecosystem
is a species whose activities have a
particularly significant role in determining
community structure.

15FD0AD069F24162A82976FA1619F0F8.description:
There are two main types of
ecological succession: primary and
secondary succession.

5D67F440A12D4531B4960DCB13E52786.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

35C03A3966EF4B6697C46A3C3AB7F43A.description:
Environmental changes, either sudden or
gradual, may threaten a speciesâ survival,
requiring individuals to alter behaviors,
move, or perish.

C5275E48D29B4D1D8137F34C5AEEC6E3.description:
Organisms adapt to their environment over
time, both in short- and long-term scales, via
incremental changes at the genetic level.

312F65459FB341B3A1EC33E763F423D3.description:
Describe how organisms
adapt to their environment.

C264940443A24C408B5DCA8CE5756911.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

F971649F0642413C9BE38F6760A61132.description:
Wildlife engages in both short- and long-term
migration for a variety of reasons, including
natural disruptions.

DB6C95D03E68491A914CCD5847702271.description:
Major environmental change or upheaval
commonly results in large swathes of

FE9E71281D1F4B1F948321453F9E1D1B.description:
Sea level has varied significantly as a result of
changes in the amount of glacial ice on Earth
over geological time.

ACD7FC8C75354AE59033FDC414D752AD.description:
Earthâs climate has changed over geological
time for many reasons.

FAD5171E0ADD42CBB91A051D829F43A6.description:
Earth system processes operate on a range
of scales in terms of time. Processes can be
periodic, episodic, or random.Â

C1BE4895E2BD469B80987FBDFDF56EBD.description:
Natural disruptions to ecosystems have
environmental consequences that may, for a
given occurrence, be as great as, or greater
than, many human-made disruptions.Â

5DE0AF9B231A4A2D87B3F33EC0EA8E59.description:
Explain how natural
disruptions, both shortand long-term, impact an
ecosystem.

91E3B966460F44119F002B55670B0B89.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

AC1AABC0C0194AE591202BD7A9288FE1.description:
Ecological tolerance can apply to individuals
and to species.

0792826C073E4358B89B9630AFD5D6AE.description:
Ecological tolerance refers to the range of
conditions, such as temperature, salinity, flow
rate, and sunlight that an organism can endure
before injury or death results.

D12CE2700F184E0289CD7B6A236D5B8A.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

A55F01EA5AB34603A55248EDCFC7F5F1.description:
Many island species have evolved to be
specialists versus generalists because of the
limited resources, such as food and territory,
on most islands. The long-term survival of

introduced and outcompete the specialists.

97F6FAED76174FB9851ACC3D7A808ACB.description:
Describe the role of island
biogeography in evolution.

939FBAC3432B48BA833A28FD8F9BFA52.description:
Islands have been colonized in the past by new
species arriving from elsewhere.

53D34EBF87974095BAD53A019ED4CE97.description:
Island biogeography is the study of the
ecological relationships and distribution of
organisms on islands, and of these organismsâ
community structures.

9D643F314B924BAD9A004F4C5D33E8B7.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

5FDC03CDB00A4944BDA260ED11855119.description:
Anthropogenic activities can disrupt
ecosystem services, potentially resulting in
economic and ecological consequences.Â

849B37D3356A4AE19B49831A2C1370AB.description:
Describe the results of
human disruptions to
ecosystem services.

A959390B58F84527860342416B7651AA.description:
There are four categories of ecosystem
services: provisioning, regulating, cultural,
and supporting.

C3CBEC94609B4B1784B8E9A1612FCBB1.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

9C7B8AD429F64177962902F16460348C.description:
Species richness refers to the number of
different species found in an ecosystem.Â

55AEE95D859F4A04B312A77314ADD86C.description:
Loss of habitat leads to a loss of specialist
species, followed by a loss of generalist
species. It also leads to reduced numbers of

Ecosystems that have a larger number

B75B0141C8634051AC1C7E37628D36EF.description:
The more genetically diverse a population is,

4F4B2C92B6EC4B82B3190D77B95A25E8.description:
Biodiversity in an ecosystem includes genetic,

A82EED8F3B45418CBBB37A35F59ED9B5.description:
Explain levels of biodiversity
and their importance to
ecosystems.

954A4112BC954E0DBD54EEF0043C1008.description: Ecosystems have structure and diversity that change over time.

568BF94929934DA79BA8B15DB4064799.description:
Positive and negative feedback loops can each
play a role in food webs. When one species is
removed from or added to a specific food web,
the rest of the food web can be affected.Â

14F55DF6560A4DFDB085B9B6DE1C38E7.description:
A food web is a model of an interlocking
pattern of food chains that depicts the
flow of energy and nutrients in two or
more food chains.

3BD6132414844538BBB831DE14172865.description:
Describe food chains
and food webs, and their
constituent members by
trophic level.

25C04BAD21F54E12937BCEA3DE332031.description: Energy can be converted from one form to another.Â

BCBE512A90E740D18C0F5CBD469C702F.description:
The loss of energy that occurs when
energy moves from lower to higher trophic
levels can be explained through the laws of
thermodynamics.

A1F4293904024002A37A4E8D6DA74C89.description:
The 10% rule approximates that in the transfer
of energy from one trophic level to the next,
only about 10% of the energy is passed on.Â

6509096083DA4943B36CDC4D145A8A1A.description:
Determine how the energy
decreases as it flows
through ecosystems.

4F4F372F710048C096AB436166150724.description: Energy can be converted from one form to another.

1CADD987ABD84DF78B08CF42C4B6D939.description:
In terrestrial and near-surface marine
communities, energy flows from the sun to
producers in the lowest trophic levels and
then upward to higher trophic levels.

6338E0ADBA4C4783B1E7A462E5E322EF.description:
Biogeochemical cycles are essential for
life and each cycle demonstrates the
conservation of matter.

535A7CB1B2A6465FAA22525AE341DB17.description:
All ecosystems depend on a continuous inflow
of high-quality energy in order to maintain their
structure and function of transferring matter
between the environment and organisms via
biogeochemical cycles.

6FFE0C35EA1E48F3A9E60497F2402386.description:
Explain how energy flows
and matter cycles through
trophic levels.

3D69395258954A9CAEB1F10653E75EEE.description: Energy can be converted from one form to another.

5BE76ED64F4D46579E443E28C217F2B0.description:
Most red light is absorbed in the upper 1m of
water, and blue light only penetrates deeper
than 100m in the clearest water. This affects
photosynthesis in aquatic ecosystems, whose
photosynthesizers have adapted mechanisms
to address the lack of visible light.Â

8BA76F23F6B9412BA4DCD956F819FD5D.description:
Productivity is measured in units of energy per
unit area per unit time (e.g., kcal/m2/yr).

BBA66EBD1B90456684E7F271086FE5C6.description:
Net primary productivity is the rate of energy
storage by photosynthesizers in a given area,
after subtracting the energy lost to respiration.Â

8EB4FEDB38B247689034035EBB59AACC.description:
Gross primary productivity is the total rate
of photosynthesis in a given area.

C53403D588334BC1BC338168353D8BE2.description:
Primary productivity is the rate at which
solar energy (sunlight) is converted into
organic compounds via photosynthesis
over a unit of time.

93383E5A9E2F488AA19EE10EF45267F8.description:
Explain how solar energy is
acquired and transferred by
living organisms.

5656A7C94F8848A3A2E8B987F6672236.description: Energy can be converted from one form to another.

B7F79F3FCB9D405391DA9D8864920BB9.description:
The oceans are the primary reservoir of
water at the Earthâs surface, with ice caps and
groundwater acting as much smaller reservoirs.

393D87067124423AAF4E996A5C73F138.description:
The hydrologic cycle, which is powered by the
sun, is the movement of water in its various
solid, liquid, and gaseous phases between
sources and sinks.

3C0CD7C28A9344EE9FED532638538C00.description:
Explain the steps and
reservoir interactions in the
hydrologic cycle.

C40E72325A3045F599AEC16FD452D9F8.description: Ecosystems are the result of biotic and abiotic interactions.

BED141B5278D4A649C3A6A201519248F.description:
There is no atmospheric component in the
phosphorus cycle, and the limitations this
imposes on the return of phosphorus from
the ocean to land make phosphorus naturally
scarce in aquatic and many terrestrial
ecosystems. In undisturbed ecosystems,
phosphorus is the limiting factor in
biological systems.

2F17B6B4A7064C61861FE907173FD690.description:
The major reservoirs of phosphorus in the
phosphorus cycle are rock and sediments that
contain phosphorus-bearing minerals.

D121DC1E9DD1451A891E42FA3598CF6E.description:
The phosphorus cycle is the movement of
atoms and molecules containing the element
phosphorus between sources and sinks.

04869ED2913F4F8EB3105DBBE0C1A814.description:
Explain the steps and
reservoir interactions in the
phosphorus cycle.

0B10A4AFA9D246408F2C929AE99363CA.description: Ecosystems are the result of biotic and abiotic interactions.

4C7B1D1111184A0CAC79C17341E7199E.description:
The atmosphere is the major reservoir
of nitrogen.

DCC1E2D6EFE140719DFF3AC195BA8EC0.description:
Nitrogen fixation is the process in which
atmospheric nitrogen is converted into a
form of nitrogen (primarily ammonia) that is
available for uptake by plants and that can be
synthesized into plant tissue.

E57B992069A047BF8F106B35FD5E333D.description:
Most of the reservoirs in which nitrogen
compounds occur in the nitrogen cycle
hold those compounds for relatively short
periods of time.

13D006EC9E3040BFAEB2F9FF6FAF45A3.description:
The nitrogen cycle is the movement of atoms
and molecules containing the element nitrogen
between sources and sinks.Â

1B6618D897914E1B96BFFE0BD15EC583.description:
Explain the steps and
reservoir interactions in the
nitrogen cycle.

F851CBD807FA40C48F2A05810A374CD6.description: Ecosystems are the result of biotic and abiotic interactions.

The burning of fossil fuels quickly moves that

8F22A4D67292422FA78F590353017E90.description:

C2197867DF7D482EA22EB1DF9A8AFFBC.description:

compounds occur in the carbon cycle hold
those compounds for long periods of time,
while some hold them for relatively short
periods of time.

AB58EC037BC441D0A69178A10D1B29CC.description:
The carbon cycle is the movement of atoms
and molecules containing the element carbon

510FB433C3CD4830AFD633A8C53AB601.description:
Explain the steps and
reservoir interactions in the

Marine biomes include oceans, coral reefs,

Competition can occur within or between
species in an ecosystem where there are
